item.title: Everyone Feared This Demonic Gang In The '80s!
item.description:
In the early 1980s four men known as the “Ripper Crew” operated in and around Chicago Illinois and were linked to a series of violent abductions and murders of women. One of their victims was 21-year-old Lorraine “Lorry” Ann Borowski who was reported missing in May 1982 while opening her real estate office; her remains were found about five months later after a lengthy search.
Thomas Kokoraleis and others in the group were later charged and convicted in connection with Borowski’s death and other crimes; Kokoraleis received a prison sentence of 70 years under a plea agreement

item.title: His Mother Was the First Person on His Kill List
item.description:
In March 2014 in Corpus Christi, Texas, 18-year-old Kevin Davis admitted fatally stabbing his mother Kimberly Hill inside their home and then turning himself in to police. Davis told officers he was responsible for the attack and cooperated during his arrest.
He later pleaded guilty to first-degree murder and received a life sentence under Texas law. The case drew attention due to his age at the time and statements he made after the incident.
Davis remains in prison and is eligible for parole decades into his sentence. Law enforcement treated the matter as an isolated domestic homicide with no further charges against others.

item.title: The Unexpected Culprit In Leslie Preer's Murder
item.description:
Leslie Preer, a 49-year-old mother from Chevy Chase Maryland, was found murdered inside her home in May 2001 after she failed to show up for work; the case went unsolved for over two decades. Police collected DNA evidence at the scene that remained unmatched until 2022 when new forensic genetic genealogy tools identified a suspect.
Investigators traced the DNA to 45-year-old Eugene Teodor Gligor, who had dated Preer’s daughter years earlier; in June 2024 authorities arrested him after obtaining a DNA sample from a discarded water bottle at an airport that matched crime scene evidence.
